Better searching and browsing

Intro - better searching.

Particularly for Lateral Reading there may be some techniques for searching and browser use that help those who do not read manuals/help pages or have not been taught this as a skill.

Search engine use

This advice may apply to site search - such as searching social media sites - in doubt check the site’s help documentation or ask others/search the web.

Search for an exact phrase

In the search box enter the exact phrase you are wanting to find but in quotes "this exact phrase"

Examples uses: you want to find pages mentioning someone’s name and job title e.g. "Sophie Corcoran" "court reporter" will find pages mentioning both the words “Sophie Corcoran” and “court reporter” (there is a Sophie Corcoran who is in the media and is not a court reporter).

Search on a particular site

In the search box of search engines adding the word site followed by a colon and a site address narrows the search to a specific domain.

Example use: finding mentions of Chiune Sugihara on the Library of Congress site. "Chiune Sugihara" site:loc.gov

Re: the domain "Chiune Sugihara" site:cnn.com retrieves a result from www.cnn.com and from lite.cnn.com

Note that the portion before the part of the domain identifying the org - for this article “cnn” is the part of the domain identifying the organisation as CNN - is a sub-domain - in these examples “www” or “lite” is the subdomain. So "Chiune Sugihara" site:cnn.com is a general search whereas "Chiune Sugihara" site:www.cnn.com searches just the www subdomain of cnn.com and would omit the lite.cnn.com result as that is in a different subdomain not included in a more general "Chiune Sugihara" site:www.cnn.com search.

Remove particular words and other options

If the search includes lots of similar results one can remove results containing particular words by prefixing a minus sign in front.

This example might see if the New York Times has articles on anyone called Serena Williams - without mentioning tennis or similar related words. "Serena Williams" -tennis -sport -athlete -venus -set -open site:nytimes.com

https://www.google.co.uk/advanced_search shows more options.

Twitter - from a particular account

To check if a particular accounts - e.g. @BBCNews on Twitter has tweeted on a subject then in Twitter search box

Greensill from:bbcnews finds Greensill tweets from @BBCNews Twitter account.

Twitter - restrict to time period

To check for a specific time period one uses the date in YYYY-MM-DD format and the since or until or both like so Greensill from:bbcnews since:2021-06-01 until:2021-06-10

This searches for Greensill in @BBCNews tweets between 1st and 10th of June 2021. Remove the since and it would be all until the 10th of June 2021 - or conversely remove the until but not the since and it would be all after the 1st of June 2021.

These kind of searches that are limited in time are great for checking if an account really did tweet something (it will not show up if since deleted but with a link to the tweet one can maybe see the original on an archive service like the Wayback Machine on archive.org).

Browser use

Some of the following tips are desktop only - as one typically does not plug a mouse into a mobile phone - nor use the keyboard in the same way.

New tabs from search results

Opening new tabs from search results - rather than using the back button to return to search results is a key timesaver.

On mobile

Long press on the link then release and choose “Open in new tab” in the menu that appears

On desktop

Right click on link and choose “Open in new tab” or hold down the Ctrl key (CMD on a Mac) and click the link.

Whichever way you do it being able to open assorted promising links from search, switch to the tabs and then close the tabs if the links are not as hoped for and return to the original search is a key time saver. If you are uncertain about switching between tabs ask someone more knowledgeable or do a search.
